III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency's program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On or around 3/5/25, a youth went AWOL from facility and was
located by EMS after the facility notified first responders. The
facility does not have adequate staffing to pursue AWOLs.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was interviewed via telephone on 3/14/2025 and
had no additional concerns.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at school on 3/6/2025.
Youth A reported she ran away from the facility due to the facility
staff not taking her to the hospital to address her wrist fracture.
Youth A reported she was with Staff 1 and informed Staff 1 her
wrist hurt. Youth A reported Staff 1 “tried to take” her to the
hospital as Staff 1 radioed another staff, unknown who, that she
was complaining of wrist pain. Youth A reported she decided
when Staff 1 radioed the other staff that she wanted to run away
from the facility as she started to have self-harming thoughts.
Youth A reported she ran out the door and left the facility. Youth A
reported staff at the facility “legally” can’t follow her when she
goes AWOLP (absent without legal permission). Youth A reported
she did not want to talk anymore.
Chief Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the
facility on 3/6/2025. Chief Administrator reported Youth A
returned to the facility on 3/5/2025 from being in inpatient care.
Chief Administrator reported Youth A was back at the facility for
approximately six hours before she went AWOLP. Upon Youth A
returning to the facility from inpatient hospitalization, Youth A
reported she was pregnant. Chief Administrator reported the
facility reached out to Youth A’s worker who approved for Youth A
to be pregnancy tested which was negative. Chief Administrator
reported Youth A later complained of wrist pain and went AWOLP
from the facility. Chief Administrator reported law enforcement
picked Youth A up from being AWOLP. Youth A informed law
2

enforcement she was suicidal, and Youth A was taken to the
hospital. Chief Administrator reported once Youth A was at the
hospital Youth A reported concerns with her wrist. Chief
Administrator reported the facility had three staff working when
Youth A went AWOLP. Chief Administrator reported Youth A has
a “constant staff” meaning the staff assigned to provide
supervision for Youth A is still in ratio however is to stay within
arm’s reach of Youth A and provide constant supervision of Youth
A. Chief Administrator reported there had been four staff on the
schedule until 7:45pm and Staff 4 was providing constant
supervision for Youth A until Staff 4 left her shift for the night and
Staff 1 took over providing constant supervision of Youth A. Chief
Administrator reported Staff 1 had just taken over providing
constant supervision for Youth A at 7:45pm and Youth A went
AWOLP at 7:47pm.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 3/6/2025.
Staff 1 reported he was working on 3/5/2025 with Youth A when
Youth A complained of wrist pain and then went AWOLP from the
facility. Staff 1 reported the facility was in ratio and had sufficient
staff as there were three staff working and he was providing
“constant supervision” of Youth A. Staff 1 reported he was sitting
outside Youth A’s bedroom door doing some beading with Youth
A. Staff 1 reported Youth A told him she had a “boxer fracture” in
her wrist. Youth A told Staff 1 while she was at Forestview
Hospital she got the “boxer fracture” and Forestview Hospital staff
told her she had a boxer fracture. Staff 1 reported he radioed
Staff 2 and informed Staff 2. Staff 1 reported Staff 2 informed him
he would contact Medical Technician to find out what they should
do. Staff 1 reported Youth A got up from beading within thirty
seconds to a minute of him radioing Staff 2 and stated, “if I don’t
get an answer, I’m leaving” and Youth A walked downstairs and
out the door. Staff 1 reported Staff 3 followed Youth A outside the
house and property until he lost a visual on Youth A. Staff 1
reported Staff 3 radioed stating she had lost sight of Youth A and
Staff 2 called law enforcement. Staff 1 reported this was the first
time Youth A indicated anything about her wrist. Staff 1 reported
earlier in the shift Youth A saying she was pregnant however a
pregnancy test was completed, and Youth A was not pregnant.
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on 3/13/2025. Staff 2
reported he worked on 3/5/2025 with Staff 1 and Staff 3. Staff 2
said the facility was in ratio as there were three staff scheduled.
Staff 2 reported Youth A was having an “amazing day” after
returning from inpatient hospitalization. He said Youth A returned
to the facility around 1pm and reintegrated back into the program
3

with no concerns. Staff 2 reported Youth A at one point wanted to
go to the hospital as she indicated she was pregnant. Staff 2
reported Youth A was given a pregnancy test which came back
negative. Staff 2 stated Staff 1 was providing constant
supervision of Youth A which, Staff 2 reported, means constant
line of supervision of Youth A with a staff always being near her.
Staff 2 reported staff, unsure if it was Staff 1 or Staff 3, followed
Youth A after she walked out the door on the facility property until
the staff lost line of sight which was when he contacted law
enforcement.
Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on 3/13/2025. Staff 3
reported she was working with other youth in the house and Staff
1 was providing constant supervision to Youth A meaning Staff 1
was side by side with Youth A. Staff 3 reported when Youth A
went AWOLP she did follow Youth A on the facility property and
when Youth A left the property and she lost line of sight, Staff 2
contacted law enforcement. Staff 3 reported Youth A frequently
goes AWOLP.
Staff 4 was interviewed via telephone on 3/14/2025. Staff 4
reported she worked on 3/5/2025 when Youth A returned to the
facility from being in inpatient care. Staff 4 reported she worked
her normal morning shift (6am-1:45pm) and then came back to
provide additional support from 4pm to around 8:15pm. Staff 4
reported she primarily was there to be a one-on-one support for
Youth A as she had just returned to the facility. Staff 4 reported
Youth A was doing well however around dinner time another youth
in the house was upset due to not liking what was for dinner,
started yelling and threw water in Staff 2’s face. Staff 4 said Youth
A witnessed this and one of Youth A’s triggers is loud noises.
Staff 4 reported she did not know if this was what later triggered
Youth A to AWOLP from the house. Staff 4 reported she left the
facility for the end of her shift around 8:15pm and Youth A was
settling down for the night due to it being close to bedtime.
Documents Reviewed:
• Youth opportunity Investments Incident Report dated
3/5/2025 for Youth A: Youth A reported she was pregnant.
Youth A was given a pregnancy test and was found not to
be pregnant. Youth A then reported she had a boxer
facture of the wrist and that she was taking herself to the
hospital. Youth A walked out of the facility and Staff 1
followed Youth A. Staff 1 attempted to use prompts to get
Youth A to return inside the facility. Staff 3 switched out
Staff 1 and remained outside with Youth A. Youth A
4

continued to not follow Staff 3’s prompts to return into the
facility and left the facility property. Staff 3 lost line of sight
on Youth A. Staff 2 contacted law enforcement and
reported Youth A as AWOLP.
• New Hope staff schedule for 3/5/2025: The schedule
showed Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3 working the 2-10:15pm
shift.
• Youth Opportunity Program Description for New Hope
Youth Center: Youth Opportunity Investments is committed
to providing high quality, evidenced based, and
individualized treatment programming for students
entrusted to our care in open residential settings.
• Youth Opportunity New Hope Youth Center Program
Description/Statement: The program has an up and awake
ratio of 1 staff to every 3 youth. New Hope cannot serve
youth with chronic and/or ongoing history of elopement.
• Youth Opportunity New Hope Youth Center Incident
Reporting Policy: When a youth is off campus, gets out of
staff’s eyesight, has the desire to evade staff, the youth is
considered AWOL. If an institution determines that a youth
is absent without legal permission, then the institution shall
immediately report the information to law enforcement,
parent/legal guardian, next of kin, licensing authority, and
the referring agency.
• Email from Foster Care Worker: AWOLP is one of the most
common ways Youth A acts out. The facility has taken
appropriate steps every time Youth A AWOLPs.
• MiSACWIS Daily Census Report dated 3/5/2025 for the
facility documented nine youth were placed at the facility.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as the facility is an open
campus that cannot prevent youth from leaving the facility. The
facility was staffed within the facilities ratio and followed the
facilities incident reporting policy as they notified law enforcement
as soon as staff lost line of sight. The facility had Staff 1 providing
constant supervision of Youth A. Youth A was followed outside by
staff.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
5

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On or around 3/5/25, the youth allegedly left due to having a wrist
fracture that was not being tended to by staff.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was interviewed via telephone on 3/14/2025 and
had no additional concerns.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at school on 3/6/2025.
Youth A reported she has a “boxer fracture” from a week ago
when she was at Forestview Hospital and fell, punched walls, and
used a boxing bag. Youth A reported after she went AWOLP from
the facility she was picked up by law enforcement and taken to the
hospital to have her wrist assessed. Youth A reported the hospital
said her wrist had been fractured however had healed. Youth A
reported the hospital advised she use Motrin or Tylenol when her
wrist is sore.
Chief Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the
facility on 3/6/2025. Chief Administrator reported Youth A had
just returned to the facility on 3/5/2025 from being in inpatient
hospitalization. Chief Administrator reported Youth A was back at
the facility for approximately six hours and had not done anything
during that time that would have caused any injury to her wrist.
Chief Administrator reported law enforcement took Youth A to the
hospital where she had an x-ray completed and there were no
fractures. Chief Administrator reported Youth A has a pattern of
finding reasons to go to the hospital as Youth A gets snacks and
is able to watch tv. Chief Administrator reported the facility has
reached out to the local hospital the facility uses and made
arrangements that this not occur. Chief Administrator reported
law enforcement took Youth A to McLaren which is another
hospital that the facility has not addressed the concerns with
regarding giving youth snacks and tv.
Medical Technician was interviewed face-to-face at the facility
on 3/6/2025. Medical Technician reported Youth A alleged she
was pregnant earlier in the shift on 3/5/2025. Medical Technician
reported Youth A was given a pregnancy test which came back
negative. Medical Technician reported she had contact with
Youth A on 3/5/2025 while at the facility and Youth A never
mentioned anything about her wrist. Medical Technician reported
she left the facility around 5pm for the day. Medical Technician
reported she received a phone call from Staff 2 around 7pm
stating Youth A was complaining about wrist pain and Youth A
was saying she had a boxer fracture however Youth A left the
6

facility and went AWOLP. Medical Technician reported the
process at the facility when a youth has something that is hurting
is for the youth to complete a “sick call” form which is then
submitted to Medical Technician to review and determine next
steps to address the medical concern. Medical Technician
reported Youth A never completed any sick call forms regarding
concerns about her wrist or a boxer fracture.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 3/6/2025.
Staff 1 reported Youth A told him she had a “boxer fracture” in her
wrist. Youth A told Staff 1 while she was at Forestview Hospital
she got the “boxer fracture” and Forestview Hospital staff told her
she had a boxer fracture. Staff 1 reported he radioed Staff 2 and
informed Staff 2. Staff 1 reported Staff 2 informed him he would
contact Medical Technician to find out what they should do. Staff
1 reported Youth A got up from beading within thirty seconds to a
minute of him radioing Staff 2 and stated, “if I don’t get an answer,
I’m leaving.” Youth A then walked downstairs and out the door.
Staff 1 reported this was the first time Youth A indicated anything
about her wrist. Staff 1 reported earlier in the shift Youth A
reported she was pregnant however a pregnancy test was
completed, and Youth A was not pregnant.
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on 3/13/2025. Staff 2
reported Youth A was upstairs with Staff 1 who was providing
constant supervision for Youth A. Staff 2 reported Staff 1 radioed
him and informed him Youth A was stating her wrist hurt and she
had a boxer fracture. Staff 2 reported he told Staff 1 to have
Youth A come downstairs to see him. Staff 2 reported he
contacted Medical Technician for guidance on how to proceed.
Staff 2 reported Medical Technician told him to look at Youth A’s
wrist, take a picture of it and send it to Medical Technician, and
provide Youth A ice. Staff 2 reported he waited a minute or two
for Youth A to come downstairs and when she did not, he radioed
back to Staff 1. Staff 2 reported Staff 1 radioed stating Youth A
was going AWOLP. Staff 2 reported Youth A was followed on
property until staff lost line of sight. Staff 2 reported he called law
enforcement after line of sight was lost. Staff 2 reported law
enforcement located Youth A and Youth A was taken to the
hospital. Staff 2 reported Youth A was assessed at the hospital
and did not have a fracture in her wrist. Staff 2 reported Youth A
had not made any comments about her wrist leading up to the
AWOLP.
Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on 3/13/2025. Staff 3
reported she had no firsthand knowledge of Youth A complaining
7

of wrist pain as she was working with other youth. Staff 3 reported
Staff 1 told her after the fact that Youth A said her wrist was
hurting and she wanted to go to the hospital. Staff 3 reported
Staff 1 told her he radioed Staff 2 to let Staff 2 who was the lead
on the shift about Youth A’s complaint. Staff 3 reported she did
not have a radio on and did not hear the radio communication
between Staff 1 and Staff 2. Staff 3 reported Youth A did go to the
hospital after being located by law enforcement. Staff 3 reported
she did not know the outcome of Youth A’s hospital visit. Staff 3
reported Youth A was calm during the shift when she was around
her and Youth A never made any statements to her about having
wrist pain.
Staff 4 was interviewed via telephone on 3/14/2025. Staff 4
reported she worked with Youth A on 3/5/2025 and Youth A never
made any complaints to her regarding her wrist hurting.
Documents Reviewed:
• McLaren Central Michigan Emergency Department
Discharge Instructions dated 3/5/2025 for Youth A: Youth A
was seen for L arm pain-swelling and suicidal ideations. X-
rays were negative for fracture. Final diagnosis: hand
contusion.
• Youth opportunity Investments Incident Report dated
3/5/2025 for Youth A: Youth A reported she was pregnant.
Youth A was given a pregnancy test and was found not to
be pregnant. Youth A then reported she had a boxer
facture of the wrist and that she was taking herself to the
hospital.
• Youth Opportunity Program Description for New Hope
Youth Center: New Hope medical staff monitor
vaccinations, health schedules, health screenings, conduct
sick call, and participate in medication dispensing and
health education to facility students.
• Youth Opportunity New Hope Youth Center Sick Call
Process, Requests, and Complaints: All youth shall be able
to make sick call requests at any time and have their
complaints treated appropriately through the sick call
system. Sick call care shall be provided by health care
professions, pursuant to their scope of practice and
according to protocols approved by the facility
administrator. The medical staff or designee shall review all
sick call requests as soon as possible but no later than four
hours after the request is submitted. Any complaint of
8

severe pain shall be treated as an emergency with
immediate notification to the facility administrator.
• Email from Foster Care Worker: Youth A has been making
false statements because she likes the attention she gets
when taken to the ER. Youth A reported being pregnant
however was pregnancy tested and was negative. Youth A
does not have a wrist fracture. The facility always takes
Youth A to the emergency room when warranted.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as Youth A had just returned to
the facility that day and upon Youth A making a statement to Staff
1 regarding her wrist, Staff 1 immediately radioed to Staff 2 to
report Youth A’s concerns and Youth A left the facility prior to the
facility having an opportunity to address Youth A’s complaint of
her wrist. Youth A was taken to the hospital after returning from
AWOLP and X-rays showed no fracture to Youth A’s wrist.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
